Derek James wrote:

>Basically, if N were set to 1 and T were set to 3.0 or
>4.0, then very large chromosomes that may have over
>99% of their topology and weights in common would be
>put into different species.  
>
Which would suggest that you need a proportional comparison. So consider 
two chromosomes A & B in the following scenarios..

Scenario 1) A.length=3, B.Length=4.
lengthDelta = 4-3 = 1;
proportional difference in size = 1/4 = 0.25


Scenario 2) A.length=300, B.Length=400.
lengthDelta = 400-300 = 100;
proportional difference in size = 100/400 = 0.25

The problem with this of course is that we allow large chromomses to 
have large differences and still be within the same species. So perhaps 
we should reduce this proportional difference figure as the chromosme 
length increases. E.g.  diff=(largeLength-smallLength)/largeLength^2  - 
or some variation on this.

Is this what you mean by 'normalizing the chromosome length'? Sorry, I'm 
feeling a bit slow today.

>So how have you guys handled these issues?  Have you
>normalized for chromosome size in your
>implementations?  If not, do you have an explosion of
>species in your populations of large chromosomes?
>  
>
On one of my better (more alert) days I did indeed implement a 
speciation system (within my own EANN project) similar to the one in 
NEAT . I used something akin to the proportion difference calculation I 
describe but I what I found frustrating was the constant having to reset 
the experiment and tweak the co-efficients and the threshhold figure to 
find good values - I guess I need a GA to search for the best parameters :)

I think it was Ken who suggested that perhaps it would be better to turn 
the whole technique on its head. Perhaps we should specify an optimal 
number of species we would like (based on population size), calculate a 
'compatibility' number for each member of the population and then divide 
them up into that number of species. Maybe this could be refined by 
adding adding special cases when the compatibility number is very small 
and very large.

>How many of you have done so?  And if you have, what
>kinds of values did you use for the compatibility
>threshold?
>  
>
Since I am not currently using NEAT the figures I use are useless to 
you. But what I did find was that small variations in the threshold 
caused either species explosions or very few species. I' m afraid I 
haven't had time to experiment further due to work commitments.

Colin.
